cons: - Low pay. I was only making $13 an hour. - You learn as as you go and they expect you to already know how to do some things. They don't teach you how to run stations. - Some older employees aren't treated fairly. - Managers are unprofessional at times.

pros: Some nice students pretty location
cons: Administration is as toxic as they come. Admin are appointed, not voted, faculty have 0 voice in administration or selecting administrators. The faculty senate formally censured the vice provost for unethical, of course, that has 0 consequence. The tenure system is a contently moving target aimed at retaining the good old boys - look at the diversity of the faculty, there is a reason and it isn't lack of applicants. Run, faculty, run.

review_title: Only do this if you're desperate
pros: I liked the other Engagement Fellows. There's no question that I enjoyed being a student at JMU, but being a recent grad and being paid $14,000 (without overtime) under the guise that this is a "year of service" is not right.
cons: We're only supposed to work 29 hours per week, a clever tactic not to provide any benefits to us as employees. This program could be beneficial if college was difficult for you or you had limited hands-on experience during your studies, but if that doesn't describe you, this is a waste of time. I did not learn any new skills. I was overworked and exploited. I had so much to offer and should have taken a full-time job instead. Avoid.

pros: There is a lot of flexibility in terms of what counts towards tenure and promotion, and there is relatively little pressure to bring in grants or publish large numbers of papers.  The students are very enthusiastic and always eager to work on projects with you. There are lots of opportunities to change your focus of you become interested in something new.  In general the university is very supportive of faculty.
cons: The teaching load is very heavy, and the time spent teaching each course is higher than at other universities due to high levels of interaction  with students during office hours and projects.   Many faculty members teach unpaid since hiring in many programs has not kept up with student growth.  Pay is getting better but still lags behind many peer institutions.  Politics can be brutal in some departments, and is particularly bad when it comes to curriculum or course changes.

pros: Good great awesome like enjoy

pros: cool job and fun people

review_title: Toxic work environment, nonexistent leadership. Only downside to my being forced out is no income for a while.
pros: Co-workers who were knowledgeable. Beautiful campus, nice little city. The workers who weren't in the "in" crowd were the most genuine and caring and, therefore, the most pleasant to work with.
cons: Narcissistic leaders bring in buddies, bully those they don't like, and take all credit for themselves. Changes are made to satisfy an agenda, not to further the work of the division. Underlings slink around and speak in whispers, looking furtively over their shoulder lest they be overheard. This is no way to work. A few who had the courage to stand up to the bullies were mysteriously gone not long after. HR is complicit in the bullying atmosphere, sitting silently in a meeting while employees are harangued and told "if you don't like it, there's the door" while being shown a picture of the door. Who wants to work for such an ogre?

pros: JMU is a good university over all. Not snobby like its neighbor in Charlottesville. I can't speak to full-time work at JMU, but as a part-time faculty member, I was allowed a lot of freedom which was a pro. The department head was not a micro-manager.
cons: The pay was pathetic for the amount of work I put in. Even as a part-time faculty, it was important to me that students received a thorough understanding of the courses taught along with feedback, etc on their work. I didn't half-ass it. But in 10 years time, I received only 1 pay increase and it was so minimal it didn't even cover the cost of gas to and from the campus/home. That is simply unacceptable. The excuse was always "the State isn't giving any increases...." Yet, full-time faculty likely received increases whether in salary or other benefits.

review_title: Best real world experience for a college student
pros: Amazing leadership opportunity. No better option for a college student to gain experience in the realm of Marketing, advertising, advertising design, journalism, newspaper management, and news website design. Not just another summer internship getting coffee and doing menial tasks.  As a student run newspaper, the students call all the shots and make almost all the decisions (both in the Editorial and Marketing/Advertising departments). Aside from two faculty advisers and an accountant, The success of The Breeze relies entirely upon the student's initiative. Faculty advisers are eager to support the good ideas of their student staffers. High turnover rate leads to more innovation and fresh content. Students must learn to balance their studies and work.
cons: Due to being staffed by college students, there is a high turnover rate (positive & negative thing). This does not allow for students to develop and see through any long term vision or plans for the company.

review_title: JMU is a 50/50 good/bad place to work
pros:
You will LOVE working at JMU -- If you work with one of the offices that fall under Student Services, or Athletics, or if you are a faculty member. 
If you are not taking a job in one of those areas, you will not like working at JMU.
cons:
Old-boy network and bullying are rampant across some pockets of the JMU administration / departments. 

A good portion of advertising for "new hires" for new positions is only advertised within the JMU community,  and existing part-time staff members get those jobs. 

Human Resources has no one to represent for "staff members." The staff's HR omsbudman position was deleted.

There is only one EEO officer for the entire university, which employs more than 4,000 faculty and staff members.

review_title: A Supportive and Professional Work Setting
pros: The students are engaged, interesting, and polite. People usually hold the door open for others and help each other out. JMU has a very positive atmosphere and people genuinely enjoy being there. Professional development opportunities abound for full-time and part-time faculty and staff. It is a very good place to develop one's teaching skills and become a highly skilled professional. Opportunities are provided for adjunct professors to design and teach new, interesting courses with ample support. The Center for Faculty Innovation is amazing. Students are well-supported with resources such as the writing center, counseling services, tutoring, health services, and others.
cons: It is almost impossible to transition from part-time teaching to a full-time position. One can teach full-time hours (38+ hours per week) for part-time pay with no benefits. Compensation is not commensurate with the cost of housing and health care.

pros: Great people, quiet town, nice facilities, great benefits, Great holiday leave
cons:
*note we are state of VA employees and JMU can't be held responsible for all of these issues*
Under paid, the cost of living in town is much higher than reported (Can't afford a house here and rent is high due to students), our graduates make more money in there starting positions than our staff does in there 2nd and 3rd positions, the pay gap between management and upper management is almost 100% or higher and between Staff and Faculty is worse, and work life balance is hard to balance because full time employee are told to expect a 40-50 hour work week when in reality we work 60-80 hour work week, & work weekends due to the nature of a college campus.

review_title: Great place to work, if and when you get hired/ Long advancement process
pros:
• Perks (Use of Recreation Facilities, Discounts on Visual & Performing Arts and Sports tickets, Seasonal Events, Opportunity to listen to Great Guest Speakers [often for free], Discounts in area with ID card, etc)
• Great Opportutnites for Training & Development
• Strong Atmosphere of Environmental Stewardship
• Beautiful, well maintained grounds
• Award winning and diverse selection of over a dozen dining locations on campus
cons:
• Slow to promote, antiquated evaluation process, overcomplicated and uncompromising hiring process. Internal departmental transfers go through same process as outside applicants, but preference given to both graduates and current employees.
• Vast differences in the way they treat Full time (called Classified) Employees and their Part time (called Wage) employees or Adjunct vs. Regular Faculty.
• Need to know people to go anywhere!

review_title: It was horrific! Do not even consider a job with them. They portray a picture of teamwork and a good environment.
job_title: Director of Foundation and Corporate Support in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: State benefits are good, but the dysfunction of the organization is not worth the compensation.
cons:
Dysfunctional management, drug abuse usage with a particular manager, micro management, ineffective communication, and the in ability to effectively lead staff in a positive team environment. 
The Assistant Manager communicates nothing, does not lead staff, does not cultivate relationships inside or outside the organization.
It is a terrible work environment where fear plays in the day to day environment of the employees.
This type of leadership should be removed from managing people. It is very unfair to the employees.
No human resource back up either! DO NOT WORK FOR THIS COMPANY...they are dangerous!

review_title: Most of the best jobs in Harrisonburg
pros: If you're a FT employee, JMU has great benefits/insurance. You can also take one class for free per semester (if you want to pursue another degree). There are many departments, lots of room for professional development, and if you don't like your job/department, it's easy to meet folks in other departments, and apply/get offered jobs they post.
cons: The pay is mediocre (not bad for Harrisonburg median income, but not great, either) and there's little chance of getting a decent raise. It's a state agency bureaucracy, so change comes very slowly. Quality of bosses varies greatly depending on department. I've had great bosses, and terrible ones. They sometimes cop out on benefits by creating 30-hour positions (where you do the same work, but don't get benefits).

job_title: Office Manager/Graphic Designer in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: In Athletics Marketing, good people/environment. Ability to work on own with minimal supervision. Weekly staff meetings to help keep everyone on track with all the projects. Opportunities to work with other departments - always a good experience. Great camaraderie with fun things to do as a team to break the work. JMU takes care of its employees - great state benefits, time off, and perks!
cons: With my current job, the only one in my department that didn't work game operations, I don't have a lot of room for growth. Collegiate Athletics has a lot of turnover with people trying to figure out where they fit in Athletics. I also have no work currently that is challenging me or helping me grow.

pros: As a student, you never know when your schedule will get crazy, but I always had the flexibility to make my own hours and get the work done in a way that fit me. I learned a lot, got to create interesting work, and always got along with colleagues while working as a designer for the Alumni Association.
cons: If too much school spirit counts as a con then I guess you could say they were the worst offenders. The pay was only minimum wage, and could have been better, but also wasn't totally unexpected while working as a student.

review_title: Good place to work as faculty and okay for students.
pros:
As a student employee it is generally fairly simple work without a boss pushing you hard to get results. For a student position, it's a great way to earn some money on the side.

Faculty pretty much only teach 8 mo of the year but are paid full time. You do the math...
cons: Student wage is pretty bad, especially considering what they think STEM majors are worth at STEM related on-campus job. Not a good career choice but it's not supposed to be, if they really paid what we're worth then we wouldn't stay focused on our studies.

review_title: JMU, A Place To Start A Future
pros: James Madison University is a great place for employment. When working for a state you know you are not going to be rich but the benefits are better than most.
cons: Being a state funded school, the past five years have been tough on the employees of the university. But the future is looking better.

review_title: Could not ask for a better place to work
pros: I have been working as a student assistant at one of the libraries there. I can't talk enough about how flexible and easy going are my supervisors. Since I am a full-time student, they are very perceptive of my study time needs and I was never asked to work during the exam week. My  coworkers very friendly and always ready to help. And I can't get enough of the gorgeous campus surroundings that I get to enjoy every day.
cons: Student Assistants usually are paid minimal wages, but hey, that pays for groceries!

review_title: Don't expect more than what you've given
job_title: Junior Data Analyst in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Community sense among coworkers, convenience of being on campus, general school year perks,  respectful students, ability to navigate the system for certain needs.
cons: Lack of information sharing, difficulty in being able to take classes for self-betterment (at a university?!), raises only when you're "a contributor" or when you receive a new position title. New positions are not created for movement, so consider if your boss doesn't want to advance, you won't be either.

review_title: An amazing, positive, supportive environment to work
job_title: Career and Academic Advisor in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: JMU is without a doubt one of the most positive places to work. Everyone, no matter what your title is, whether you are a housekeeper or a VP, is friendly and genuinely cares about students and each other.
cons: The only thing about JMU is that it's located in Harrisonburg, VA. To some, that's a positive because it's a great place to settle down and raise a family. But unless you are a college student, it's not the most exciting place to be as a young professional.

job_title: Telecommunications Teaching Assistant in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Being a teaching assistant at JMU was extremely rewarding because it gives you a chance to solidify the knowledge that you acquired while taking the course by helping others understand the material.
cons: The hardest part about holding a teaching assistant position at JMU is that you are still a full time student and have to balance your own course work with grading and other requirements.

review_title: I enjoyed working as a writing tutor.
pros: This job offers a lot of freedom. You can design your own projects to work on. You can also choose to work on the projects of others. It's a great opportunity for students.
cons: Training is a bit lacking. You'll be trained on how to tutor, but you're left on your own when it comes to knowing the content.

pros: Great work environment that makes coming to work enjoyable. Students go through training's to improve their leadership experience. Supervisors are all helpful.
cons: The pay is minimal and can take a lot of time during the week while going to classes. There are a lot of rules for students that can make it hard to enjoy.

review_title: A good university to work for.
job_title: Planetarium Staff, Research Assistant in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Fair hiring practices, respects students' needs, okay pay for college kids. Great jobs for applicants who are not students, and good job fairs ever fall and spring.
cons: Some of the downsides were that, unless you looked hard,  you would most likely work at dining services or as a tutor. Harrisonburg, VA is very nearly in the middle of nowhere.

pros: UREC is an unbelievable organization within James Madison to work for. The amount of attention the staff pay to train student employees and create a culture of inclusiveness and teamwork is truly what makes it special. There is not a day that you will go to work without being greeted with a genuine smile or personality.
cons: (Like most on-campus jobs) the pay isn't the best, however the opportunity to learn and be a part of a community most definitely outweighs the poor pay.

pros: JMU has a generally supportive atmosphere and is a gorgeous campus; graduate students with assistantships can get free tuition and monthly stipend.
cons: Graduate student pay is low ($9k-12k per year), and the university doesn't offer healthcare to graduate students (an already vulnerable population).  Travel is only reimbursed, never fronted. The office culture varies wildly between departments, so be careful when applying.

pros: Very relaxed work enviornment, with much support from faculty and staff to accomplish the given tasks.  The atmosphere is very friendly and encouraging.
cons: The relaxed work environment can be a blessing and a curse as they leave it up to the individual to complete work in a timely manner.

pros:
* colleagues were great to work with and I enjoyed my 9 years as a educator
* strong students coming into JMU College of Business
* outstanding community
cons:
* difficult administration to develop instrinsic motivation to go above and beyond to achieve life long success. 
* it was more important to tow the company line than it was to achieve exceptional results in or out of the classroom. 
* adherance to unstated policies was expected

pros:
It gives reasonable financial compensation in exchange for good work experience.
Being a research assistant while being enrolled as a student looks good as experience on a resume.
There is schedule flexibility.
cons: The income for being a research assistant is not always as competitive as some other part time work in the area.

pros: Generally very flexible.  Management realizes that they are working with other people, not just a number of employees and that is important to them.  Creates a really good dynamic between managers and employees.
cons: Employees are probably not paid enough for the work that they are doing, there isn't a ton of space for promotions.

review_title: Music Library is a good place to work when you have multiple activities to juggle.
pros: Flexible schedule and good work environment.  Staff is very nice and helpful.
cons: tasks are repetative and sometimes boring.  A lot of downtime when business is slow and the customers can sometimes put a damper on the day.

job_title: Tech Desk Student Assistant & TA in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Working for professors or other facility is incredibly rewarding, very flexible schedule, everyone is willing to help you out if something unexpected occurs in your life, no money wasted on gas since you can walk to where ever you work even if you don't live on campus, a great opportunity to meet other students who are always friendly
cons: Low pay compared to other part time jobs one can get

review_title: Good place to work, but like most jobs, a lot of satisfaction will depend on who you work with.
pros: Good benefits, and access to lots of resources through the library and trainings. If you can find time, you can take a class or two for free.
cons: If you're working in an academic department, and don't have a terminal degree, some people might treat you differently (less than) they treat those with a Ph.D.

pros: Relaxing atmosphere with lots of kind people. Overall I like the working conditions and the hours. My co-workers were always willing to help.
cons: No advancement opportunities at the time. I was not moving in a direction that would allow me to grow and increase my skills

review_title: Overall an excellent place to work.
job_title: Administrative & Professional Faculty in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Opportunity for credit and non-credit training was extensive. Facilities were excellent. City was safe and peaceful, yet diverse and entertaining. Campus is beautiful. Vast majority of people were quite nice to work with at JMU.
cons: Some budgets are too tight. Some individuals are brilliant, but simultaneously uber territorial, competitive and narcissistic.

review_title: Good Flexible experience at the Computer Labs
job_title: Micro Computing Lab Assistant in Harrisonburg, VA
pros:
-Pretty flexible in terms of hours and fairly relaxed atmosphere.
-Provided some exercise while checking other labs.
-Provided opportunities to help students with more complex computing issues.
cons:
-Could have been paid a bit more after a year's tenure and job well done.
-Some minor office drama. (I avoided these things)

pros: JMU is a great place to work with a good work/life balance. Benefits are pretty good and time off is really nice. You can look up their HR policies online since they are public.
cons: It's a state university so some salaries are low until you get up to a high managerial level, but that is the norm in most gov't positions.

review_title: Reffing is fun but not worth the pay.
pros: Fun people to work with and incredibly flexible hours. They do the best they feasibly can to train you.
cons: Minimum wage and high stress environment. Especially for basketball. There are just too many games to ensure high quality referees. I don't know of anyone being turned away or fired.

review_title: Great Experience with the JMU physics department
pros: Relaxed work environment and a very good support network. Whenever I had a question I had no shortage of people who were willing and able to help me.
cons: I only had issues with filling out the same forms for multiple offices. There was a major lack of interoffice communication on campus. This is my only complaint

pros: I enjoyed flexible hours, holidays and snow days off, and decent pay. Definitely a good option for anyone in the Harrisonburg area!
cons: There haven't been raises in a long time. I worked in a very old building that needed renovating.

pros: Great school with terrific professors and opportunities
cons: Enrollment policy leads to many students needing to take an extra semester. Additionally there handling of the Covid outbreak has been awful and frankly shady. They send students home saying they will be able to come back just so they don't have to offer refunds for room and board

review_title: Pleasant, I work at the Forbes Center for the Performing Arts and I love it!
pros: Everyone is easy to talk to, accommodating, and is willing to work with your schedule if you're a student.
cons: Deadlines come fast and often, but since I am a graphic designer, that is to be expected. A fast paced environment encourages productivity anyway.

pros: I was paid well and it was convenient while in school.  I could pick my own hours and had a very flexible schedule.
cons: Nothing really.  I enjoyed working here and would definitely recommend it to current or prospective students

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Everyone is extremely friendly. Students are great! Faculty and Staff are very welcoming. The culture of the university is amazing. It is not intimidating to ask questions.
cons: I have no cons about working for James Madison University

review_title: Great place to work and raise a family
pros: Beautiful campus, jobs pay more than fairly for the area
cons: Can be hard to integrate into for outsiders, there is a definite campus culture that permeates everything, staff tends to stay in positions forever so not a lot of opportunity for advancement

job_title: Commercial Loan Review Manager in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: JMU offers a lot of great benefits for full time employees - health, dental, vision, tuition reimbursement, employee groups and support systems
cons: Unless you are an AP faculty, or administrative head, the general pay across the board is pretty low. Admin assistant positions that require bachelors degrees should not start in the 20s.

pros: Great people that provide exceptional training in order to complete your job to the best of your ability and purposefully.
cons: Salaries a little low, I don't know what the minimum wage is in Virginia but they good possibly bump some hourly salaries up a bit.

job_title: Program Administrative Manager II in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: dependable work; you are working for a state organization
cons: Sometimes working for a state organization can seem tedious as many rules have to be followed that a business perhaps does not need to follow, but it's dependable, solid, steady work

pros: People are really friendly. Work environment is fun, Harrisonburg is a cool place to live in.
cons: There was a job turnover for a high ranking position and they promoted someone from the inside that didn't have good rapport with the existing employees instead of other great options

pros: Great students to work with. The area is very beautiful.
cons: School is very slow to change. Has some very archaic tools, policies, and procedures.

pros:
Fair management with reasonable expectations.
Reasonable hours worked, with salary pay appropriate for length of work.
Free gym access.
Great food.
cons:
Jealous of all the students currently there.
Sometimes long hours of working indoors during the summer.

pros: Very flexible hours. Lots of responsibility. Independence highly rewarded. Decent pay for the work.
cons: Managing the warehouse could be difficult at times because it is largely unsupervised and there are inherent dangers that come with operating forklifts

pros: Good environment, good students, beautiful city, low cost of living, reasonable salary, mostly four year college but reasonable research is going on, shared labs and instruments
cons: teaching is the main goal, somehow dominating research which is understandable for the kind of institute it is.

review_title: Great work-life balance, but lack of resources is an issue.
pros:
Friendly workplace
Great work-life balance
Focus on growth and innovation
Excellent benefits
cons:
Lack of resources for program and projects
Bit of an "old boys club" in the leadership levels

pros: Great learning experience, friendly workers and great boss
cons: A little too lax at times. Made me too comfortable with not finishing work on time.

review_title: Amazing place to work and develop professionally
pros: There are so many opportunities to learn and grow. It's not only about the tasks, it's about you as well!
cons: You may not get as much time as you'd like to -- especially if you're part time.

pros: Great place to work, they offer work study programs, internships, and paid positions for their students. They work around class schedules and give students valuable job training.
cons: Small budget for increasing technology in the marketing department.

pros: One of the best things I did while in College. Meet lots of new friends. Establish lot's of connections.
cons: Bad scheduling system. Can't get shifts covered sometimes.

review_title: Overall a good place to work
pros:
Fridays off at noon during the summer
Lots of opportunities for professional development
Staff are friendly and supportive
cons: Pay is much lower compared with UVA or profession as a whole. Once you accept a salary it is difficult to advance.

review_title: Great place to work - good culture, family
pros: The Madison culture is truly a great place to be - the student body has a wonderful and positive spirit.
cons: Not a lot to do in Harrisonburg and didn't always agree with university policies.

pros: Supportive of every single employee and their needs; paid training sessions and guest speakers; ability to move up quickly in the ranks; great atmosphere
cons: Very popular place to work and is highly competitive with thousands of applicants per semester

review_title: Treat Employees Kindly but without over the top perks
pros: Nice facilities and nice well-being programs devoted to employees
cons: Could be more perks for personal development. Opportunities are there but you have to go kind of out of your way to obtain them.

review_title: Great Start to a Job in Technology
job_title: UREC Technology Specialist in Harrisonburg, VA
pros:
Exposure to new software (Signwave, Keywatcher, Fusion). 
Flexible hours. 
Incredibly kind staff.
Dress attire is easy- the purple UREC shift 
The job is never stressful.
cons: I don't have any cons for working at UREC.

review_title: Awesome Job, Learn a lot and earn money at the same time
pros:
-Get one on one interaction with your professor
-Get leadership and communication skills
-Become a better teacher
-Help students with their problems
cons: -Could use a little bit more money

pros: If you're full time with benefits, this is one of the best places in the area to work.
cons: JMU has some toxic undernotes to its employee culture, depending on where you work.

pros: I've met some of the most wonderful co-workers and students I could ever hope for
cons: Faculty, staff and students generally are not treated well. There is mistrust, secrecy, and some nasty politics going on in the background.

pros: Very nice biology department. Beautiful campus. Lots of food options. Respectful students. Good resources for students and teachers
cons: Food is a bit expensive. Sometimes it takes too long to get something done within the department

review_title: Working at JMU was a good experience for me. Although it was only for a short amount of time, I learned a lot.
pros:
Laid Back
Flexible schedule for student
cons: Sometimes there wouldn't me enough work for me to do.

pros: I love the people and the environment. They successfully make employees feel like part of a team.
cons: Pay is minimum wage, but that is fair considering the work is not hard and it is very flexible.

review_title: Have a skill you teach? No time to maintain the skills.
pros: Nice people. Creativity supported.
cons:
Work Load
Pay is not equal to rank or longevity at JMU.

job_title: Customer Support Specialist in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Very kind people, get to learn a lot, cheap living area
cons: The town is very small and at times there is not much to do.

pros: Good benefits, beautiful location, nice facilities
cons: Heavy workload/teaching load, “leadership” lacking at administration, level, lack of intellectual curiosity on campus, lack of diversity, generic institution, pay is low compared to other VA institutions

pros: Friendly people who help each other and not very competitive.
cons: Heavy teaching load, 3 or 4 courses every semester.

pros: great people, great culture. JMU is a special place and working here was a privilege as a student. Hope to return someday.
cons: Pay is probably a little on the low side.

pros: Excellent people, benefits, and students.  The work at this institution is really impacting so many lives.
cons: Very few, but can be hard to advance to major leadership positions.

review_title: PASS Leader/Tutor in Chemistry and Biochemistry
pros: Significant contribution to my living costs in the United States during my undergraduate program.
cons: No significant downside in working at JMU.

review_title: Nice Place to Work - good culture
pros: Well paid.  Collegial environment
cons: Growing; not sure when it will stop.

review_title: Great place to work, but compensation is on the lower side
pros: Flexible, lots of paid time off, good benefits
cons: You have to pay for parking, compensation low and raises don't happen often

review_title: It's a great place to work.  I will hopefully retire from JMU someday.
pros: Well paid compared to peer institutions.
cons: Pay raises have not happened in awhile.

review_title: Amazing opportunity for growth in leadership and sales!
job_title: Caller Development Manager in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Commitment Level,Location , Pay, Employee Meals, Flexible Hours
cons: Dealing with upset alum over the phone

pros: Good faculty and student body
cons: administrators not trusting or listening to faculty

pros: Very little to no micromanaging
cons: I was the first person to have this position, so I trained myself

pros: Friendly people, never a dull moment
cons: Huge turnover, little job security, questionable managerial decisions, not enough compensation

pros:
- training opportunities through HR in multiple competencies
- excellent benefits including PTO and educational benefits
cons:
- not every department is as friendly as others
- low salary

review_title: Takes care of student employees very well.
pros: The school ensures jobs for students and accommodates all types of schedules.
cons: There aren't any cons from my experience.

review_title: Science and Math Learning Center tutor
pros:
*I enjoyed helping those taking a class in my subject area
*Coworkers were fantastic
cons: *Sometimes scheduling can get a little hectic.

review_title: It is an OK place to teach.
pros: Nice people and pretty environment
cons: Faculty salaries are not competitive and teaching -intensive.

review_title: Low Pay, Nice place to work
pros: Enjoyable job, co-workers, and management. Professors are compassionate and caring.
cons: Lab can get stressful when many assignments are due.

pros: Allows students to get experience for their resume. Allows student to prioritize school if needed.
cons: None comes to mind now

pros: Flexible hours, easy job, worked for a nice professor
cons: I was only allowed to work up to 6 hours per week

pros: Benefits, work/life balance, professional development opportunities
cons: As a state agency, raises are more infrequent than in the private sector.

pros: relaxed environment, great coworkers, great managers
cons: Not many. Its a great job for a student at JMU.

job_title: Assistant Director of Event Management in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Wonderful benefits and lovely people in all staffing areas
cons: None! Nothing that you wouldn't find at other jobs

pros:
-Organization promotes work-life balance
-Best "on-campus" job @ JMU
cons: -Lots of headaches from residents

review_title: Adjunct teaching for numerous years satisfying
pros: Great professionals. Wonderful students. Opportunities to take leadership positions.
cons: As with most adjunct positions, little pay

job_title: Office Assistant in East Quogue, NY
pros: Excellent work environment, dedicated people to work with.
cons: Did not get compensation enough for the amount of hours put in.

job_title: Linguistic Specialist and Medical Interpreter in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Great pay, work atmosphere, support system, and place to advance
cons: Hard to find a place to park

pros: Friendly environment and welcoming community to work in
cons: Lower pay compared to other companies

pros: Excellent management, flexible hours, portfolio builder.
cons: I honestly have no cons for working for the College of Business.

job_title: MAD CON Caller in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Very convenient hours and fun people
cons: Not much room for mobility or incentive to do well

pros: Campus life, clubs, facilities, science program
cons: Some professors clearly did not want to teach but wanted to do research.

pros:
- good experience 
- great learning environment
cons: - not the best pay in the world

review_title: JMU is a great place to work
job_title: Assistant Director of Web Marketing in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Great benefits, flexible work/life balance
cons: Lots of construction on a very busy campus

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: good pay good benifits good vacation
cons: the politics are crazy here

pros: Very kind and easy to work with management
cons: Not best pay ever but fair

pros: Flexible Hours, Decent Pay, Zero Hassle
cons: None, Great place to work

pros: Amazing people, great opportunities for future employment
cons: Expensive, can be a bit big

job_title: Senior Assistant Director of Admissions in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Positive Work place for recent graduates.
cons: State institution with a lot of red tape.

pros: Great! I really enjoy working here
cons: I have no comments for this section

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: benefits, independence, beauty of campus, everyone is happy
cons: too much money spent on athletics

pros: Benefits, location, environment, tuition waiver program
cons: Economy, budget restraints allow no room for financial growth

review_title: It has been a great experience.
pros: flexible hours and good communication.
cons: low wages, could be better.

pros: good pay and benefits offered
cons: too many cliques make it difficult

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Amazing boss and very supportive colleagues.
cons: Location may be too rural for some

pros: A good place to start, plenty of holidays, benefits, etc.
cons: It's easy to get stuck here.

pros: Hours are good and pay is great.
cons: Small place and hard to park.

pros: Positive org culture is paramount.
cons: Faculty salaries are not competitive.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Flexible, Good pay, willing to work with you
cons: No cons come to mind

pros: Team environment and management are helpful
cons: Stressful night shifts and not much flexibility for shifts

pros: Flexible Hours and easy work
cons: Underpaid and often doing last minute tasks

pros: Very family-like feel within the department
cons: We have to pay for parking passes

pros: Flexibility and great advancement opportunities

Student employee
